This is probably the only female Ninja movie ever made. It's great as a B film and the action sequences are a lot of fun to watch. This is a well invested crowdfunded project and I definitely think it stands up. I enjoyed it from start to finish. The acting could have been better and the sex scenes were a tad too drawn out (even for a B movie), but overall I think it was a very enjoyable film and bonus "the best bits"

I loved October Sky. The thing I loved most had to be the music. It worked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives off a sense of hunger competition between the tribes, capture music and compete for women. Then as it builds towards the summary from Native Americans, the music seems to overwhelm you with a sense of loss of culture and identity.
Jim Sheridan documents his family & work life in profound ways. His dad passed away whilst making the film

I first saw this one when it was first shown, so I'm not too objective about it. It really managed to scare me, partly because it was a fairly simple, effective ghost ride, and partly because it held together through my often frustrating inability to watch three pictures in a row. Even if it isn't as coherent as other Tobe Hooper films I've seen, if I ever find it on screen again, I'm going to be seeing it.
star star

Latter Days is a very, VERY independent movie. And compared to many of today's more modern films, it's lacking on many parts. The shooting. The acting. How the characters talk to each other. The story. The overall vibe of the movie. But looking at it from a more old school, horror-riffic one, I'm not messing with Barbie in this movie. Start paying attention though.
